newsitem.title: JAPAN: Big bet that went awry for Japan opposition leader.
newsitem.headline: Big bet that went awry for Japan opposition leader.

text.p: Japan's controversial opposition leader Ichiro Ozawa gambled big -- and lost big -- when he bet voters would set aside distaste for his backroom fixer image and give him a shot at the nation's top post.

The humiliating setback for his Shinshinto (New Frontier Party) raises doubts about the future of Ozawa, once seen as a key candidate for prime minister, and about prospects for a viable two-party system, political pundits said on Monday.

Shinshinto -- born of a broad coalition that ended the Liberal Democratic Party's (LDP) monopoly on power in 1993 -- won only 156 seats in Sunday's general election, four fewer than it held before the vote.
The LDP secured 239 seats, 12 short of the majority it needed to rule alone but enough to ensure its president, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, would head Japan's next government.

On Monday, speculation mounted that Ozawa, whose penchant for high-handed tactics won as many enemies as his reformist vision won admirers, would be forced to resign as party chief or see his organisation split.
Either way, analysts and Japanese media said, Shinshinto looked set to see 10 or more members defect.
"We were unable to win full support and we have to look into what made our presentation not that effective," Shinshinto Lower House member Isamu Ueda told Reuters.

Some analysts said Ozawa, 54, was all but certain to step down from the top party post. "In the code of Japanese politics, he has pretty much said that he had to go," said John Neuffer, political analyst at Mitsui Marine Research Institute.
Others said that forecast might be premature.
"I think the only way he will step down (as party leader) would be if he had a good plan for how he would step back up," quipped one former aide to a Shinshinto MP.

A longtime rival of Hashimoto who once pulled premiers' strings like a master puppeteer, he bolted from the LDP in 1993 to become key strategist for the coalition that robbed the LDP of sole power in 1993.

His attempt to spell out in some detail a vision that included reforms to spur policy debate and loosen the web of regulations that gives bureaucrats such arbitrary power won plaudits -- especially among American officials seeking reforms in Japan's economy.
Such views have now become standard fare from politicians of nearly every stripe, although some sceptics doubt how sincere many really are.

Shinshinto's reliance for key support on a lay Buddhist group, the Soka Gakkai, also turned away many voters, as did a series of strategic missteps stemming from Ozawa's autocratic style, analysts said.

"Ozawa made two mistakes -- his tie-up with Soka Gakkai, which made it difficult to get majority support, and his attempt to monopolise power within the party," said political commentator Minoru Morita.
Voters appeared unmoved by Ozawa's efforts to woo them ahead of the election with pledges to hold down the three percent sales tax while enacting hefty income tax cuts.
"That was a surprising error," said Roger Buckley, a professor at International Christian University in Tokyo.
"Maybe it was a sign of desperation."
Despite the fractured state of Japan's opposition, analysts said a viable second party could eventually emerge.

"The silver lining for the opposition is the huge number of apathetic voters," Neuffer said, noting that some 40 percent of the electorate failed to vote at all. "If the opposition can tap into the apathetic electorate, they could be a force to be reckoned with."
